<Link id="l00773" /><CodeLine lineNumber="773"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Avoid using conditional returns at the end of a loop (since then</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00774" /><CodeLine lineNumber="774"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// we&#39;d need to emit an unconditional branch to the beginning anyway,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00775" /><CodeLine lineNumber="775"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// making the loop body longer).  This doesn&#39;t apply for low-probability</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00776" /><CodeLine lineNumber="776"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// loops (eg. compare-and-swap retry), so just decide based on branch</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00777" /><CodeLine lineNumber="777"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// probability instead of looping structure.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00778" /><CodeLine lineNumber="778"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// However, since Compare and Trap instructions cost the same as a regular</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00779" /><CodeLine lineNumber="779"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Compare instruction, we should allow the if conversion to convert this</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00780" /><CodeLine lineNumber="780"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// into a Conditional Compare regardless of the branch probability.</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00783" /><CodeLine lineNumber="783"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeywordFlow">return</span><span class="doxyHighlight"> </span><span class="doxyHighlightKeyword">false</span><span class="doxyHighlight">;</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01336" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1336"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01337" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1337"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Look for cases where the source of a simple store or the destination</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01338" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1338"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// of a simple load is being spilled.  Try to use MVC instead.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01339" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1339"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01340" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1340"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Although MVC is in practice a fast choice in these cases, it is still</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01341" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1341"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// logically a bytewise copy.  This means that we cannot use it if the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01342" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1342"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// load or store is volatile.  We also wouldn&#39;t be able to use MVC if</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01343" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1343"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the two memories partially overlap, but that case cannot occur here,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01344" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1344"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// because we know that one of the memories is a full frame index.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01345" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1345"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01346" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1346"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For performance reasons, we also want to avoid using MVC if the addresses</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01347" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1347"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// might be equal.  We don&#39;t worry about that case here, because spill slot</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l01528" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1528"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For reassociable FP operations, any loads have been purposefully left</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01529" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1529"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// unfolded so that MachineCombiner can do its work on reg/reg</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01530" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1530"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// opcodes. After that, as many loads as possible are now folded.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01531" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1531"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// TODO: This may be beneficial with other opcodes as well as machine-sink</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l01532" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1532"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// can move loads close to their user in a different MBB, which the isel</span></CodeLine>
